title: penarth businesses residents speak council plans
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityPenarth Town Council hasstressed the ideas are "points for discussion" before a formal proposal is put to the Vale Council. They also said a trial period will not take place in August and September.Ideas, revealed by the town council in an online questionnaire on Friday, includes a pedestrianised ldquosafe space on Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout, including the bottom of Lower Glebe Street.Other plans for Windsor Road could include ldquoshared spaces between pedestrians and traffic during set times, while another included only allowing service traffic ndash such as delivery vehicles ndash to access Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street.One of the major points for discussion is around proposals for a one-way traffic system incorporating Albert Road, Stanwell Road, Hickman Road, Arcot Street,Glebe Street and Ludlow Lane.The grey area marks the safe space pedestrianised proposal.The town council say the one-way system would enable more chevron parking on Plassey Street, Albert Road and Stanwell Road.Ceri McCann, Rachel Came and Karen Hatton at Andrearsquos Flower Boutique on Glebe Street, think the town will sufferpedestrianisation plans go ahead.: Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" alt"Penarth Times: : Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" class"editor-image": Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe StreetldquoPenarth isnrsquot the type of place you come to and spend a day, itrsquos a place people come and park up and quickly do some shopping, they said. ldquoBusinesses are already feeling the impact of lower footfall due to the social distancing parking trials, and to add this to the mix is poor timing.The plans also include additional bus stops, including one right outside Joan Painesrsquo funeral directors.The new ideas are designed to bring an additional  spaces to the town centre, but this is likely to affect residentsShe says buses stopping outside her shop every half an hour - combined with the one-way system - would be likely to cause too much congestion.ldquoMy main concern is the congestion and the impact that will have on my customers, she said. ldquoIt is not nice to have so much noise, fumes, and congestion outside when yoursquore trying to sort out a funeral.Joan and Tony Paines have made a blown up version of the main town area, so people can better understand the ideas.Ms Paines suggested a bus terminal at Station Approach, and said she thinks a one-way system around the town will also cause heavy traffic on smaller roads such as Railway Terrace, Grove Terrace and Woodland Place.Resident and member of Friendsof the Earth Barry andVale Max Wallis said he is in support of partial pedestrianisation, but questioned the one-way system idea.Mr Wallis said that a one-way system would ldquoworsen traffic and add to town centre pollution, adding: ldquoCovid- will force new thinking. People see the benefits of more walking and cycling. Some shops and businesses will close, with more online shopping. The town centre must become more a meeting and activity place access by bus or bike is more attractive withthe reduced traffic.       ,params: .pushMax WallisStrategic consultant John Jackson, who lives in Penarth, is in favour of partial pedestrianisation of Windsor Road on a trial basis.ldquoThis system works abroad, and works abroad in places where the weather isnrsquot always nice, he said. ldquoI think Penarth needs to be a more attractive environment post lockdown, and that would involve some sort of pedestrianisation.ldquoI think the idea to close off Windsor Road from Lower Glebe Street to the roundabout isnrsquot a bad one, and could instil some confidence for future changes.ldquoWhat I would question is whether the timing is right so soon after businesses have reopened.Five hundred people have responded to the town council survey so far.Cllr Nigel Humphrey - for St Augustines - said: ldquoPeople have been responding to the survey asit is a done deal, when in fact it is intended as part of a constructive dialogue about the future of our town centre."Gideon Calder of Gwyrddio Penarth Greeningsaid: ldquoFrom conversations with people, some are assuming that the current arrangement in the town centre ndash the bollards and one-way system ndash is the same thing as these alternative ideas about creating safer space."In fact these plans are quite dferent. Theyrsquore intended as a solutionto many of the problems which people are identying with things as they are.In a questionnaire circulated to traders by Penarth Business Group which waspassed onto the town council, of the  responders , . per cent said they against partof Windsor Road becoming a traffic free zone. . per cent said they were in favour of a one-way system being introduced to the town centre. . per cent said they were in favour of using wider roads for chevron parking.If you would like to find out more about the proposals visithttps:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk news penarth-post-covid-your-views-on-our-town-centre .If you would like to make your views known but cannot access the survey online, you can call Penarth Town Council on   Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Many staff took on dferent roles to normal, as some services were shut while other new ones were needed.Council workers organised covid- tests for both staff and residents arranged for businesses to be given breaks in paying rates and awarded almost pound million in grants to local businesses from the Welsh Government.Cllr Moore said: ldquoNone of us have sat back during this pandemic. It has been a dficult time and much work has gone on in the background. Itrsquos important to note the amount and complexity of the work our staff have carried out to keep the majority of our services in operation. Itrsquos a huge gratitude we have to give to our staff.ldquoThere has been an absolute willingness to experiment and take some measured risks, which have to be done under the circumstances. Projects have been driven through at an unusual pace.Cabinet member for social care and health, Cllr Ben Gray said: ldquoResponding to this emergency has been an incredibly complex task with many moving parts mdash one that isnrsquot over yet.ldquoStaff have continued to support those with profound disabilities. Carers are key workers who have been putting themselves in harmrsquos way to provide their most dedicated support for our most vulnerable. I canrsquot thank them enough.The next issues the council will face is how to reopen schools safely in September preparing town centres for non-essential shops opening and managing car parks now the five-mile travel rule has been lted.While schools were first shut and lessons began over the internet, some children struggled with a lack of technology at home. But the council provided laptops and internet to those in need.Cabinet member for education, Cllr Lis Burnett said: ldquoOur children werenrsquot left without IT connectivity. Our IT department provided  laptops or tablets to children, and  wi devices for children who didnrsquot have broadband.Builders are carrying on building new schools in the Vale, on socially distanced construction sites with contracts awarded locally.She said: ldquoWe havenrsquot stopped our st Century schools building programme, but delivered it in a very socially distanced way. The new building at Pencoedtre High School has started and that complements Whitmore High School and the work at Ysgol Bro Morgannwg.ldquoIn the next few months we should see three new primary schools considered at the planning committee. One will be low carbon and the other two zero-carbon, which I understand will be the first in Wales.ldquoIn such dficult times, itrsquos important to keep employment going where possible, and this is evident with the economic impact of our schools building programme. Museum on Wednesday, September  and the National Wool Museum on Thursday, September .To ensure the visitor experience is as safe and enjoyable as possible, Amgueddfa Cymru has introduced a range of general of Amgueddfa Cymru, David Anderson said: ldquoWersquore all looking forward to welcoming our visitors back to our national museums."Although our buildings were closed, we have been open online and on our digital s.ldquoDuring the closures we have had a fantastic response to our lsquoCollecting Covidrsquo project asking the people of Wales to be part of the story by sharing their experiences and feelings of living in Wales during pandemic. This will form an important record for future generations.Amgueddfa Cymru ndash National Museum Wales is a family of seven museums and a collections centre, which are all free to enter thanks to the support of the Welsh Government.Together, it is home to the nationrsquos art, history and science collections, which will continue to grow so that they can be used and enjoyed by both present and future generations.Registered charity Amgueddfa Cymru is grateful for all support.The events and exhibitions programme is supported by players of the Peoplersquos Postcode Lottery.During this period a number of Amgueddfarsquos popular events can be enjoyed from home online.Find out more about the Amgueddfa Cymru digital food festival and Museum Sleepover: Dino Nights! title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Air ambulance takes motorcyclist to hospital after serious RTCSadness as funeral of popular Co Armagh woman takes place todayNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . story: NI man is finalist in ‘Shed of the Year’Police uncover £, worth of Class A and B drugsNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleLockdown blues of -year-old Vera lted by call from Daniel O’DonnellA -year-old lady from Portadown was thrilled to receive a video message from her favourite singer, Daniel O’Donnell, during lockdown.By Helen McGurkTuesday, th August , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th August , : pm""Vera recceiving her call from Daniel ODonnellVera Purdy, who receives home care from Home Instead Senior Care Banbridge, confided in her caregiver about feeling isolated during the nationwide lockdown, which has prevented her from seeing friends and family.Vera’s caregiver knew that she enjoyed listening to Daniel O’Donnell, so set about with the rest of the Home Instead team to try and get in touch with him.They contacted his management team and told them all about how Vera was Daniel’s biggest fan, having gone to see him at many of his concerts over the years. Daniel recorded a -minute personalised video message for Vera and sent it over to the Home Instead care team. He remembered meeting Vera many years ago, and even remembered her late husband and mother’s names. He also recalled Vera and her family coming to watch him at his concerts and entertaining the family at her mother’s th birthday party.Vera was delighted with the video message. Her caregiver recorded her reaction as she watched the video, and her face lit up. She has watched the video over and over, and has happily ed back to her normal, positive self. Vera said: “It has given me such a boost.”But more was to follow. As pleased as Vera was with the video message, she was even more delighted when she received a call from Daniel himself on the following Sunday evening. He called for a chat with Vera to reminisce about the past and expressed how pleased he was hear from Home Instead.He said he was impressed how Home Instead had gone above and beyond to ensure her happiness.Roisin McLeod, care manager at Home Instead Banbridge, said: “It was great to see Vera so happy and joyful.“Although we are regular visitors of our clients, lockdown has still been tough for many. “Gestures of kindness such as the video message from Daniel are massively appreciated and help remind our older generation that they aren’t alone during these uncertain times.”""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  .
